comments.commentBody: To put it bluntly, I think iCloud sucks. My contacts are synced to my Mac and they show up on iCloud.com. However, when I set my iPhone 4 to sync from iCloud instead of from my Mac, my contacts disappeared. I don't know if anything else was missing, but I promptly stopped syncing over iCloud and started syncing from my Mac again. I love cloud technology (Google's is excellent) and I will use it, IF it works. I don't see the point in using iCloud when there are so many other reliable cloud services out there (such as Google--its services work just fine on the iPhone, and have for several years now). Apple's products are supposed to "just work." iCloud does not "just work." I predict iCloud will be a dismal failure. I hope I'm wrong.

I'm only commenting and repeating other's disappointments because I hope that someone at Apple might pay attention to David's readers.

I am sick at the loss of the MobileMe gallery and iDisk. I have older Macs that run Leopard just fine and one that can run Lion but need older applications that will not run without Rosetta, so no Lion in my future. Also, my .me mail will go away because without Lion no iCloud is possible.

iMad.

Once someone invokes the phrase "god said" - rational conversation ceases.
The term - "in God we trust" should be stricken from our money.
Bachmann may believe that some god gave her whatever insight into how the world works, but her law degree should be about law - not religion.
That debate was fought over two centuries ago - when the Constitution was written and rational conversations about law and religion led to the notion that a government should be separated from religion.
This country is based on laws we, as a community of people accept, - not a religion imposed by a majority.
If we lose that fundamental structure - we are lost as a nation.

My initial reaction to article was of heightend interest in Rep. Bachman. So far I have been impressed with her enthusiasm and response to her supporters. If ORU turned out a bright studhent like Michelle Bachman, it has good things going for it. I am sorry to hear this innovative law school failed, but glad that Regent was able to continue the mission of ORU; as well as their excellent library.

Like many Conservatives/Republicans, I feel our country has lost it's common sense. All this effort to tear down public postings of the 10 Commandments, possibly the best blueprint for civilization ever developed - - just amazes me. What a sad and very wasteful effort! The very first letter supports tolerance of Sharia Law, what ignorance. I would love to see those supporters of Sharia have a personal "experential" taste of it. When I saw one of my favorite causes, The Southern Poverty Law Center, embrace tolerance of Sharia and mock the work of Rep. King, I could have cried. How did they ever
go so far astray in their embrace of compassion and benovolence. Saddest of all I am only the 2nd Consernvative posting, right now. How sad this once great paper is now only read by one type of person. I can still hope the Times might respond with a piece written by somebody who loves/venerates ORU. We do not get a good objective picture of this school. If that is no longer the goal of NYT, all I can say is what goes round will come back to bite ya.

“The only reason we’ve been a great nation — guess why? Because at our founding we established everything we did on the lordship of Christ.”

I think our country's greatness is due to our diversity. All of the great inventions, businesses, athletes, etc... have emerged from a very diverse group of Americans hailing from various religious and non-religious backgrounds. Our nuclear program (and current national security guarantor quite frankly) was largely developed by Jewish scientists for example. I don't understand how these Christian zealots came to believe that they and their religion are responsible for our country's success. Certainly Christians have made substantial contributions but people like Bachmann and her cohort of ignorant followers are anything but reflective of our country's greatness.
American Theocracy, scary stuff aka Flat Earth Society.

I have absolutely nothing kind to say about Michelle Bachman, but I am starting to be concerned about the media's obsession with her. If you'd leave it alone, she would be a has-been in a matter of weeks. She is at the bottom of the pile of GOP prez hopefuls; she accomplishes nothing in Congress but uses it simply as a podium for her fringe minority beliefs, which is exactly what she represents.

Indeed, you can ignore the entire Christian far-right and the country will be better off. They represent maybe, MAYBE, 20% (I think closer to 15 if that) of the electorate and yet they control the debate because you hand them the mic and turn up the volume every time they want to say something. The white, conservative, evangelical Christian right should be free to believe and act as they please, but there is no reason the entire country should act as though they represent majority will. They simply do not, no matter how much their delusion drives them to believe otherwise.

Interesting that Mr. Titus should mention Romans 13, which states quite clearly the necessity of submission to governing authorities.  If our Founding Fathers took that verse literally, they would: a) never have rebelled; b) have paid taxes to England without complaint.

Stop it. I guess it's all well and good to have the law and religion intertwined when it's your religion of choice - not anyone else's.

The strain of the GOP that Bachmann and her ilk represent only reinforce the idea that the U.S. is nothing more than a party joke to the rest of the world.

Oh, how one wishes to be tolerant and inclusive in one's view of religion--especially those of other people---but this is just too much. Yes, let her be taken seriously as the US Representative of her district in Minnesota, but , no, we cannot under any circumstances take her seriously as a potential president of the United States.

Her beliefs would have been outside the mainstream even fifty or seventy-five years ago, but in our media age, her attractive appearance, well-spoken manner, and slick packaging overcome too much rational assessment of her as would be somewhat more the case without our video universe, and more of the printed word.

(And, besides, her appalling misunderstandings of American history are truly mind-boggling. Forget religion--she knows nothing about this country before 1975 or so, and the history thereafter is superficial.)

I do agree that church and state cannot be *strictly* separated -- we're human, after all, and we are going to work within our belief systems as we see fit.

But.

We can at the very least try. This is a pluralistic society and nation. Anyone who is going to run for a major office owes that sort of integrity to all of his or her putative constituents. If not, bow out and go run for an office like dog-catcher, where it won't really matter.

Bachmann is a religiuos fanatic. It is hard to believe that people who were her mentors exist in our country. And these people complain about Islamic countries where relgion and state is all combined. I am glad we have seperation of relgion and state and that needs to be guarded with passion.

No candidate with strong religious views can win the white house. Everybody including herslef knows it well. But still they play this game of religions in politics, Religions divide people. we need to go back to the human root before Christ or prophet or any other religious leader was born. Religion is based on a belief. That belief was required to explain things before the science was matured. There are over 732 religions and many thousands sects and subsects of these relgions. how would you unite these diverse groups? Only one way is to preach humanity for peace (live and let leave) - the root of human origin on the basis of science not belief as our knowledge grows.

Don't you get it by now?  None of these Repubs are serious.  They are clowns.  They are in it for the campaign contributions that are almost guaranteed as soon as they spout certains likes about Christianity, hearing things from God and that other American religion, "the free market."  The money pours in, they get rich.  It has nothing to do about winning the Presidency or even the prinmaries.  Maybe it would happen.  That would be nice.  But that's not Bachmann's, or Perry's or Cain's or any of the other clowns' objections.  10 Clara Belles, squirting water in everyone face...with many of their contributors pretending they aren't getting wet.
Reporting like this is the reason I gladly send them my money every month!

@9. Kleinau Carbondale, Il October 13th, 2011 6:02 pm
"Now you see, this is what is great about America. Writer number 3 is frightened by knowing that Bachmann attended a law school where Christian based judgment was important. For me it is just the opposite. Until I read the article I wasn't interested in Bachmann, now I am. Wow, would't it be wonderful to get someone in that office that really cared about the Golden Rule."

Yeah, it would be wonderful. But what makes you believe Michelle Bachman cares about the Golden Rule? Since when is lying okay under the Golden Rule or the Ten Commandments? Misrepresentative Bachman's pronouncements about history, the Constitution and the intent of the founders are laughable. Let's not forget the recent uproar caused by her false claims regarding the HPV vaccine. And here's another Bachman absurdity: "I find it interesting that it was back in the 1970s that the swine flu broke out then under Democrat President Jimmy Carter. And I’m not blaming this on President Obama, I just think it is an interesting coincidence." (Michelle Bachman, April 28, 2009)
Here's some advice for Mrs. Bachman and the other Republican candidates:
"Better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to speak out and remove all doubt."
Abraham Lincoln, 16th president of US (1809 - 1865)

Wow, I forgot Anita Hill worked at Oral Roberts.  I hope I get to forget Bachmann completely.  Come on, those poor evangelicals always get punked by the RNC.  Unless the church puts their own money into their own manipulating, as did the Mormons in California, they never will get their way.  This is America, for god's sake.

Ms. Bachman hasn't the capability to guide and nurture her own household.  It angers me to have to be made aware of the ciphers currently running for the Republican nomination in a newspaper of the quality and stature of The NY Times.  If you must run such stories, please bury such stories.

"Politics is not religion and we should govern on the basis of evidence, not theology." Bill Clinton
The candidates "calling" are for the Papacy.
She was ahead of the trend in our curent American education system, she dumbed down before the bush years of underfunded NCLB.

Michelle Bachmann is an idiot savant. She is capable of mouthing slogans but little else. Her world view is, to say the least, so parochial as to be embarassing to any who hear it.  She is, however, typical of what the modern day GOP offers the electorate: neofascistic fundamentalist fanatics of limited experience and less sense. Despicable.
Informative article, but why the use of "were" in the headline?  She's never stopped believing that there should be no separation of church and state.
Michelle Bachman's "beliefs" are warped -- or, at least, what she projects about her "beliefs" -- but it says far more about the country than her that anyone gives her the time of day.

Ms. Bachmann was indoctrinated in the belief that . . . .

“God is the source of law; the Constitution is akin to a biblical covenant, binding on future generations; the founders did not intend for a strict separation of church and state . . . .

"[a] philosophy [which] has its best-known advocate in Mrs. Bachmann [who has] exposed a wider audience of Americans to views long espoused by social conservative scholars."

A major reason that presidential candidates find it productive to pander to ultraconservative radicals is this article. ‘Scholars?’ Please. Giving credence to such believers as “scholars” is a travesty. These beliefs do not constitute a “philosophy” – they are, instead, indoctrination – propaganda of the most destructive kind, promulgated by charlatans. The New York Times should be performing its societal role by speaking out against such simplistic anti-intellectual nonsense and speaking up for intellectual honesty and reason.

The law school no longer exists. It was shut down and whatever tatters remained opened in Virginia as Regent Law School. So her degree is basically meaningless in today's terms. Surprise, surprise, surprise.
